headNote.p: Sanger drew from these notes for a speech to the First Ohio State Conference on Birth Control, held at the Hotel Gibson. Other speakers included Juliet Barrett Rublee, Eleanor Rowland Wembridge, and Jerome Fisher. Sanger's speech have been supplemented with quotes from "Birth Control," Catholic Telegraph, Nov. 23, 1922. Sanger drafted very similar notes for speeches given in Buffalo on Feb. 9, 1922 (MSM S70:928), Indianapolis on Nov. 18, 1922 (MSM S70:946), and Vancouver, Canada on July 3, 1923 (MSM S70:1000).

p.q: Mrs. Sanger rang the changes on the deplorable conditions brought about by the reproduction of the insane, the feeble-minded, the tubercular, the very poor, and the dependant. She told touching stories of young couples, struggling with adversity and babies during the first years of their married life. She described the hardships of poor mothers with large families. She said that it was cruel to deny the means of preventing conception to a woman, who does not want children; and she stated that abortion is very commonly practiced.

As an alleged panacea for all this and much more, Mrs. Sanger prescribes a system of birth control, which would provide physicians and nurses to intrust females in the ways and means of preventing conception. She claims these as some of the advantages of her system:

div.p: Newly-weds could enjoy marital life a year or so without fear of pregnancy. Women, who want children, can have children when they wish; and women, who do not like babies, need not have any. Parents can put more into the raising of a few children; and "we want a race of thoroughbreds."
